Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: May 25, 2009 06:44AM don23 wrote: Had my surgery Friday 5/22. Came home from hospital Sat. 5/23 in the evening. Couldn't sleep in that hospital bed anymore! Felt better when I got home. I had a bilateral mx with expanders puts in. Surgeon was able to keep a lot of my skin so he said I would only maybe need one fill. I hope he's right! I cam home with two drains and a pain pump in place so I'm really not in any pain. Just uncomfortable. I have a question for anybody that might know this answer. I did have a sentinel node biopsy and they only took two of the sentinel nodes out and none others. Preliminary findings were negative-have to wait for final path report. She did not take any other nodes out? Is that common? I thought they always took the sentinel along with others. Surgeon assured me it is all she needed. I a little nervous that she didn't take more. Any answers?
Posts.Title: May 2009 surgery lovinmomma dkhancock1948

Posts.Content: Jun 16, 2009 06:49AM don23 wrote: Thanks ladies! It doesn't sound like it will be too bad. I just wanted to prepare myself if it would be like 20 or more pounds. I guess if I eat a lot that might be a problem but I will try sticking to eating healthy and trying to fit in some kind of fitness. Thanks again!
Posts.Title: Weight gain don23 otter

Posts.Content: don23 wrote: I just met with my oncologist to find out what treatment plan is in my future. Right now she says that I could either do TC x 4 or TAC x 6. We are waiting for the oncotype test to be done to see which form of treatment. I hope it comes back with a low number so I only have to do four rounds. Anyway, I asked her about the side effects such as weight gain and she said I would gain weight but didn't tell me how much (because everybody is different). Can any of you ladies out there shed some light on this?????? I need to prepare myself! Dx 4/10/2009, IDC, 1cm, Stage I, Grade 2, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Weight gain don23 otter

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 03:14PM don23 wrote: It took six weeks for me from the time I was diagnosed and the actual surgery. I thought I was going to lose my mind in between that time. The doctors kept telling me it would be ok to wait that long. I had a hard time believing them but had no choice. I had a bilateral mastectomy with tissue expanders at the same time and that is what held up my surgery. Both the breast surgeon and the plastic surgeon have to be there and they had to coordinate their schedules. I was so relieved when my surgery day came. I wasn't even emotional that day. I worried so much before that day that I don't think I had any more worries in me - just relief to get it over with! See if one of your doctors can prescribe something for your anxiety. It really helped me get through those days. Since my surgery, I haven't needed to take anything. Hope this helps you. Best of luck to you and keep us updated. Donna
Posts.Title: How long between diagnosis and surgery or treatment? Anxiousmama katiec

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2010 02:22PM don23 wrote: My PS brought four different sizes in. Good thing because he ended up using the biggest size he brought in. What my PS does is puts the sizer for the implant in - sits you up (while you're still under) to see how it looks. If it looks OK he puts the actual implant in. I would definitely let him know your thoughts on how big you want to be, etc. well in advance of your exchange surgery. It's good to be on the same page so you won't be disappointed after.
Posts.Title: Question about exchange surgery... travelgal6979 MBJ

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2009 10:50AM don23 wrote: To some having the healthy breast removed is overkill and they don't do it.  I did not have to have a bilateral but chose to for peace of mind. I don't think I could have lived each day wondering if I would get cancer in the healthy one. Everything I felt would feel like a tumor and I didn't want to live that way. My surgeon did not persuade me one way or the other. It was my decision. I do not have any regrets (surgery was in May). For me it was the right choice. For some others it might not be. It is a personal decision that only you can make. Good luck to you. Whatever you decide will be right for you.
Posts.Title: What made you decide . . . Mantra Mantra

Good luck in making your decision. Donna

Good luck to you!

Posts.Title: Stage 1, Grade 2, ER+ PR+ HER-, Node-Negative, Onca 20 Chemo???? limegreen Plils

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2009 10:11PM don23 wrote: I was dx on April 10 and didn't have my surgery until May 22nd. I was like you and was worried that things were taking too long. I discussed this with my surgeon and she said it was Ok to wait that long. Sometimes it takes two months. If you have reconstruction at the same time of surgery, the two surgeons need to collaborate in order to find a suitable time that fits both of their schedules. I was told that the tumor takes so many years to grow that a few months doesn't make that much difference. I know that is hard to hear at this time but hang tough! You will get through this! By the time your surgery date comes you will feel more relieved and then you'll be glad that part is over.

Posts.Content: Dec 2, 2009 10:48AM don23 wrote: gcarter - I have the same feelings as you do with guilt on your outcome. I had a BMX with TE's. No chemo for me either (oncotype score of 11). I did attend a bc support group but felt like I didn't belong there. Hearing the women talk about chemo, etc. made me feel guilty for being there because I did not have to go through any of that. I left the meeting feeling very guilty and sad. Hence, I never went back. I have since found a support group for mastectomy patients and am going to give that one a try. Maybe I will fit in there. I, too, was more nervous about my exchange surgery than the BMX but everything went smoothly and honestly I really didn't have much pain. It was a piece of cake compared to the BMX. I am now four weeks out from my exchange and have to say things are starting to soften up and taking shape. Happy Birthday to you and good luck on Tuesday.

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2010 02:00PM don23 wrote: catbill - I have had the exchange to implants and I will tell you it definitely is better than the TEs. Are you getting silicone implants or saline? I have the silicone and they are so much softer than the TEs. You will be amazed at the difference.  I know by the time I had my last fill before my exchange things were a little tight for a day or two. If you are in a lot of pain the PS can take some fluid out and go slower with the fills.  Do you know when you will be getting the exchange to implants yet?

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2010 11:53AM don23 wrote: inthepink - I have a similar diagnosis except mine was Grade 2. I had a BMX with reconstruction. My BS said I only needed a lumpectomy but I decided on the BMX. Long story short - my right breast was always the lumpy one and it turns out I got cancer in my left one. I would have driven myself crazy wondering if the lumps I felt were cancer or not so I decided on the BMX for peace of mind. I did not have to do radiation or chemo. I had the oncotype test done and it came back with a score of 11 which is considered low.  I did get two opinions on the chemo thing and one told me I could do if I want and the other one said chemo would not benefit me. I trusted the advice of the 2nd opinion because she specializes in breast cancer oncology. I was then put on tamoxifen for 11 months. Had a hyster/ooph in May and just started on Arimidex July 1st. So far so good. I also don't think the type of surgery you get depends on if you get chemo or not. Hope your oncotype score comes back low and maybe that decision will be made for you. Good luck!

Posts.Content: Sep 14, 2010 01:00PM don23 wrote: I did stay overnight in the hospital. I had a BMX with tissue expanders as well as the sentinel node biopsy. It was a Friday and I got to my room at about 5:00 pm. I was released on the next day, Saturday at about 6:00 pm and that was only because I was nauseous in the morning and they wanted to make sure I'd be OK. By the afternoon I was fine. They said I could stay another day if  I wanted to but I had a moaning room mate and I just wanted to go home.
Posts.Title: Is it typical to be admitted as obs pt with bxm and TE surgery michelekb lovesnature

Posts.Content: Sep 18, 2009 10:28AM don23 wrote: I have not had my exchange surgery yet (scheduled for Nov. 4th) but the ps said I would have drains in for at least 5 days - UGH! When I had my bilateral mastectomy I had two drains in for 2 1/2 weeks. Hopefully with the exchange it will only be five days. I do know that some ps do not do drains with the exchange. I wish mine was one of them.
Posts.Title: Drains after bilateral mastectomy-questions! SDinSDCA Alfieval

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2010 10:01PM don23 wrote: Do you know for sure that you will have to have drains? Some PS do not use them for the exchange and some do. I did not have drains with my exchange. Had my exchange done on a Wednesday and was back at work the following Tuesday. I could have went back on Monday but already had it scheduled to be off. I would check with your PS to see what he has to say. Sometimes they may have to do extra work and that might add time to your recovery. Maybe you can schedule an appt. w/PS to discuss what he plans on doing and then you can figure out how long you might need. Good luck to you.

Had my exchange done on a Wednesday and was back at work the following Tuesday. I could have went back on Monday but already had it scheduled to be off. I would check with your PS to see what he has to say. Sometimes they may have to do extra work and that might add time to your recovery. Maybe you can schedule an appt. w/PS to discuss what he plans on doing and then you can figure out how long you might need. Good luck to you.
